End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to add to her savings to build a new house

loans.name: Mrs. Chhin Srey Touch's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Thirteen people in Oknha Pang Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia, have formed a village bank loan group. Each member plans to use the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Chhim S. T. has been selected by the members to be the village bank president. She owns a small place where she sells sugar and canned juice. Mrs. Chhim S. T. is 33 years old and the mother of two children who attend the local school. 

Her husband, Mr. Yuos Chan Serey, is a soldier who uses his small salaR. to support their living conditions. Although Mrs. Chhim S. T. and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot support her family well. 

Mrs. Chhim S. T. has decided to ask for a loan that she will use withher savings to buy motorbike for her husband. He wants to be a motorbike taxi driver when he is not working as a soldier.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Six members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. The members with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the veR. end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to add to her saving to buy motorbike for her husband to start motorbike taxi driver.

loans.name: Mrs. Yo Srey Mao's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Thirteen people in Oknha Pang Village in Kampong Chhnang Province make up this village bank and they will use the loan which they hope to obtain for different purposes.

Mrs. Yo S. M. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She owns a small grocery store in the local village. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery products for her inventory. Her husband, Mr. Ruos Vannak, is a soldier who can only make a small salary to support his household. Mrs. Yo S. M. is a 21-year-old mother with no children yet.

Mr. Chhem S. was not present at the meeting but his wife was, so she is present in the photo instead of her husband.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Six members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more grocery products for her inventory

loans.name: Dominga

texts.es:
Con más de 20 años en el negocio de la crianza de chanchos, la señora Dominga, de 54 años,  también vende menúes afuera de un colegio de su barrio. Con sus 5 hijos ya mayores, ella se encarga de su nieta mayor, en edad escolar. A la señora no le han pasado los años en vano y el día a día, en la crianza de chanchos, se le hace más difícil, sin embargo, ella no declina y su mirada se mantiene optimista con respecto al porvenir que quiere trazarle a su nieta.
Para tan ardua labor necesita de 800 soles de préstamo, en aras de cubrir los gastos que le depararían la compra de alimentos para sus animales y la elaboración de las comidas que expende.
texts.en:
With more than 20 years' experience raising pork, Dominga, aged 54 years, also occupies her time selling foods outside a school in her neighbourhood. Her five children are now of age, but she takes care of her eldest granddaughter who is still schoolaged. To her the years have not been passed in vain, and her day to day chores raising livestock is getting harder. But nontheless, she never gives up and her outlook remains optimistic in providing for her granddaughter.

For her hard work, she requires a loan amounting to 800 soles, with which she will cover the expenses she will encounter when purchasing feed for her animals, and for the production of foods that she sells.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase feed for her pork to make them ready for sale at Christmas and to purchase the necessary ingredients for the her food sales.

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Kheng's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of thirteen people, is located in Bompong Phchoek Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Sok K. is village bank president. She is a basket maker in the local village. Aside from this business, she is a poultry breeder who raises chicken. Mrs. Sok K. is a 44-year-old widow with four children, two of whom help with their mother's businesses, while the others are attending the local school. Although Mrs. Sok K. and children try to help each other to earn a living, they still live in an old house. To improve her living conditions, Mrs. Sok K. decided to ask for a loan to buy zincs to fix her roof during the rainy season. 
 
All the members in this village bank have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These allow thE. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients stA. to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase zincs to fix her roof during the rainy season.

loans.name: Mrs. Rith Sambath's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Rith S. is the president of a village bank that consists of fourteen people who live in Bompong Phchoek Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. Mrs. Rith S. makes baskets in the local village. Her husband, Mr. Suk Sao, is a fisherman who gathers a little fish to support his family.

Mrs. Rith S. is 41 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is a fisherman. The others are enrolled in the local school. Although Mrs. Rith S.'s family members have different businesses, they still live in an old house with a leaking roof. In order to repair this roof, Mrs. Rith S. has decided to ask for a loan to buy zinc strips to replace the old roof.

All of the members in this village bank have end-of-term (EoT) loans, so they are not required to pay aN. principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments maN. months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy zinc strips to replace the old roof.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Teresa Jesús

texts.es:
Con 50 años, la señora Teresa cuenta con 2 ingresos, uno como ayudante de cocina en un comedor popular de la zona donde vive y, otro, vendiendo cosméticos por catálogo de una prestigiosa entidad en el rubro. Al empeñar tanto esfuerzo en ambos trabajos y, al ver deteriorada su salud incluso más por dicha labor, es que anhela ambientar en su casa un espacio para el expendio de comidas basadas en pescados y mariscos. Su anhelo está cimentado en la sonrisa de sus 3 menores hijos, en el de 18 años que maneja mototaxis para darle una mano en casa y los de 15 y 12 que cursan el colegio.

Con vistas a invertir en mercadería para la venta por campaña, la señora Teresa requiere de 600 soles, para seguir labrando sus pasos hacia el anhelo que añora.
texts.en:
Mrs. Teresa is 50 years old and has two sources of income. She helps in the kitchen of a popular restaurant in her neighborhood, and also sells cosmetics from the catalog of a prestigious local organization. Teresa invests a lot of effort into both jobs, and is seeing her health deteriorate faster because of it. Teresa would like to renovate part of her home to sell home-cooked fish and seafood meals. Her dream is founded in the smiles of her three youngest children, in her 18 year old son who drives motorcycle-taxis to help her support the family, and her 15 and 12 year old children who are in high school. With hopes of investing in merchandise to sell, Teresa needs 600 soles to continue taking steps toward the dream that she yearns for.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To be able to invest in cosmetics, in preparation for high demand during the Christmas season.

loans.name: Mrs. Um Or's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank located in Bompong Phchoek Village in Kampong Chhnang Province consists of nine people and they plan to use the loan which they hope to obtain fO. different purposes.

Mrs. Um O. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a basket maker. Her husband, Mr. Sin C., is an animal catcher who goes hunting in the forest. They have five children, one of whom is a fisherman while the other two assist their father in the business. The remaining two are attending the local school. Their first child's business now faces a small problem because his boat motO. needs to be repaired so that child cannot catch fish to support the family. Thus, Mrs. Um O. decided to ask fO. a loan to buy a new boat motO. fO. her child to restart his fishing business.

Mrs. Kom N. and Mrs. Yav K. did not come to the meeting but their husbands were there, so they are present in the picture instead of their wives. Mrs. Men Yoem is a group guarantee and she is also shown in the picture in the village bank loan.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Eight members have end-of-term loans and the other has a monthly payment loan. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poO.. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a new boat motor for her first child to restart his fishing business

loans.name: Mrs. Meas Seng's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Meas S. is a group leader of four, who all live in Sam Raong Village in Takeo Province. She is a 58-year-old widow with five children, one of whom is a farmer, while another two are attending the local school. The remaining two are too young to work or study because they are at the ages of one and five years old.

Mrs. Meas S. has a small piece of land where she cultivates rice to earn a living. In this business, she now faces a small problem because her field is infertile, which is having a bad effect on her crop. To solve this problem, Mrs. Meas S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support her field to make her crop more productive.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Two members have end-of-term loans and the other two have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to support her field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.es:
A pasos agigantados, la señora Cristina, de 40 años, ha logrado situar su restaurante en el barrio con gran acogida, en su local vende menúes y cervezas, también lleva menúes a casas de zonas cercanas, siendo aun más su demanda y, a la vez, necesidad de insumos que requiere para su elaboración. Tiene bajo su tutela a una hija de 22 años, a quien busca apoyar en su educación superior pero hasta el momento no le es posible.

En aras de poder brindarle tamaña dicha, como lo es la educación superior en el Perú, es que solicita encarecidamente el préstamo de 800 soles, los que le servirían para abastecerse de lo necesario así como de agregarle raíces al sueño que quiere hacerle alcanzar a su hija.
texts.en:
Mrs Christina, is 40 years old and very rapidly, she has succeeded in establishing a restaurant in her neighborhood. The restaurant, where she sells daily menus and beer, has been very well received by customers. Moreover, she also delivers the menus to the surrounding areas. Currently, as demand has grown, she needs more supplies to prepare the menus. Mrs Christina has to provide for her 22 year old daughter, who lives at home and who would like to continue her undergraduate education. However, Mrs Christina is not able to pay for it. And in order to give such joy to her daughter, she heartedly requests a loan of 800 soles. She will use the loan to buy supplies for her restaurant and cement the posibility to make her daughter's dream a reality.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will use the loan to buy supplies for her restaurant

loans.name: Mrs. Kuy Nary's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of twelve members, is located in Prasung Village in Takeo Province. Mrs. Kuy N. is the village bank president, who has been selected by the members. She is 49 years old and a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it, S. she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions after she sells her new pigs. Her husband, Mr. Chab Nan, is a motorbike taxi driver who can generate a small income to support his household. Mrs. Kuy N. has two children, who are attending the local school.

A man who is present in the picture came to accept the loan instead of Mrs. Ngil T., his wife.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Five members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Mrs. Mach Van's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Seventeen people in Boeng Tranh Village in Takeo Province make up this village bank loan group and they plan to use the loan which they obtained for different purposes. Mrs. Mach V. is the village bank president who has selected by the members. She is a silk weaver in the local village. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more silk to weave to meet her customers’ demand. Her husband, Mr. Suong Sokheng, is a construction worker, who can onL. make very little income to meet his famiL.'s expenses. Mrs. Mach V. is 28 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is at the age of two.

Mr. Som S. did not come to accept the loan but his wife did and is present in the picture instead.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainL. end-of-term loans. Twelve members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthL. payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financialL. able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of onL. 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more silk to weave to reach her customers’ demand.

loans.name: Ruth Aleli

texts.es:
Con 23 años, la señora Aleli se dedica a la venta de telas en Gamarra, La Victoria, uno de los centros industriales más importantes del país, con 2 años de experiencia y con 4 como madre soltera, su hijo acaba de entrar al colegio, es que ha decidido independizarse en el negocio (actualmente trabaja para una señora) porque sabe que le esperan largos años de brindarle educación a su único hijo. Es una tarea ardua pero la carrera ya la he emprendido por el bienestar de los 2.

Para seguir edificando su futuro, la señora solicita el préstamo de 600, dinero que financiaría la inversión a realizar en las telas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aleli is 23 years old and sells fabrics in Gamarra, La Victoria, which is one of the most important industrial centers of the country. She has two years of experience in this business and has been a single mother for four years. Her son just entered school and Aleli would like to use the business to become independent (right now she works for another lady). Aleli knows that there are long years ahead during which she'll provide an education for her only son. Her work is hard but Aleli's career has already started to benefit the wellbeing of her and her son. To continue building her future, Aleli is asking for a loan of 600 soles, which will finance an investment in fabrics.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in fabrics to earn more income.

loans.name: Musarat's Group

texts.en:
Musarat baji is the widow of J. I. and lives in a historical place named Yadgar of the city Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this place for the last 17 years. She is the mother of five children: four sons and one daughter. Her eldest son runs a mobile shop. The next to him is a tailor and completed his education till 8th standard. Her daughter stays at home and does household work.

Musarat baji herself has a clothes selling business. She has been in this business for the last 18 years. She buys clothes from a big clothing market named “Shahalmi and Feroz pur Road”. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to resell.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Kosar baji wants a loan to buy construction supplies (cement and sand) to resell. Shaista baji wants a loan to buy medicines to resell. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy more clothes to resell. Fazilat baji wants a loan to buy a lathe machine.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Rubina's Group

texts.en:
Rubina baji is the wife of T. M. and they live in Yadgar in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house, where she has lived for 19 years. She is the mother of ten children: five sons and five daughters. Three sons are house painters. The others are free and don’t do anything. Her daughters stay at home and do household work.

Rubina baji is a seamstress and sews clothes to order. Her daughters help her cut out the dresses. Rubina baji successfully repaid her previous two loans from Asasah. She requests a loan to buy another sewing machine so that she can complete the previous orders more quickly and get new orders.

She has several other members in her loan group. Rehana baji requests a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy clothes to resell. Samina baji requests a loan to buy paint brushes to resell.

loans.use: Buy another sewing machine to product dresses more quickly

loans.name: Mrs. Mey Khorn's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank, which consists of seventeen members, is located in Boeng Tranh Village in Takeo Province and all the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Mey K. is the village bank president and she is a pig breeder. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets. She will use the rest of the loan to purchase pig food to feed her pigs. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions after she sells the new pigs. Mrs. Mey K. is a 62-year-old widow with a child who is a taxi driver, who can make a small income to support the famiL..

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainL. end-of-term loans. Seven members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthL. payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financialL. able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of onL. 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and purchase pig food to feed her pigs.

loans.name: Maritza Ingrid

texts.es:
Con apenas 1 año de abierta su tienda, la señora Ingrid, de 33 años, ha crecido vertiginosamente, para el bien de su familia, conformada por su esposo y su hija de 2 años. Empero del buen comienzo que ha tenido su tienda, le es escaso el capital que puede invertir en mercadería, manteniendo una ínfima cantidad de ganancias, lo que aumenta la preocupación para con su hija y sus futuros años, que la insertarán en el colegio.

Para lograr dicho objetivo y, mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia en sí, es que necesita de un préstamo de 500 soles.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ingrid is 33 years old and opened her store little more than one year ago. It has grown rapidly in that time, and has benefited her family, which consists of her husband and two year old daughter. In spite of the great start that her store has had, Ingrid lacks the capital to invest in merchandise, which keeps her earnings extremely low. Because of this, Ingrid worries about her daughter and the upcoming years, when she'll start school. To achieve this objective and improve the quality of life for her family, Ingrid needs a loan of 500 soles.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supply the products necessary for her store, primarily beer

loans.name: Iqra's Group

texts.en:
Iqra baji is the wife of A. H. R. and lives in a place named Yadgar of the city Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this place for the last 14 years. She is the mother of six chidren: four daughters and two sons. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Iqra baji’s husband runs a PCO, having 10 years' experience there. Iqra baji herself runs an academy where she teaches students of different subjects. Iqra baji is an educated lady and completed her education till 10th standard. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy mobile phone cards for her husband’s PCO.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Kishwar baji wants a loan to buy leather to resell. Fozia baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Bushra baji wants a loan to buy a lathe machine. Zeenat baji wants a loan to buy flour for her bread-making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy mobile phone cards

loans.name: Mrs. Phouk An Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phouk A. is a group leader of four, who all live in Pun Phnum Village in Takeo Province. She owns a hectare plot of land where she cA. cultivate rice to earn a living. In her plantation, she now faces a small problem because her field is infertile, which has a bad effect on her crop. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Phouk A. decided to ask for a loA. to buy fertilizers to support her crop to make it more productive. Her husband, Mr. Nu Veasna, is a construction worker who cA. earn a small income to support his family. Mrs. Phouk A. is 34 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is at the age of four years.

Mrs. Moeu M. did not come to accept the loA., but her husband did so he is present in the picture.

All the members in this group loA. have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loA. until the very end of the loA. term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loA. term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to support her crop to make it more productive.

loans.name: Mrs. Uon Khoeurn's Group

texts.en:
Four people in Sdok Prei Village in Takeo Province make up this group loan and Mrs. Uon K. is the group leader. She is a farmer and pig breeder. Since the second business is going well, she wants to expand it so she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding.

Her husband, Mr. Eng Sok, is a recyclable goods collector who usually buys empty bottles, cans, and plastics to re-sell in recycling factory. Mrs. Uon K. is 28 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled the local school while the remaining one is too young to work or study because that child is only one year old.

loans.use: to buy more piglets for breeding

loans.name: Francisca Pilar

texts.es:
De 30 años de edad, la señora Pilar tiene más de 10 años de experiencia en el negocio de transportes de carga pesada. En un ambiente de su casa ha puesto una bodega-librería y en las tardes ejerce su profesión: es maestra de primaria (aunque de manera particular, en su misma casa). La señora Pilar no cesa de soñar cada vez en más grande, por lo que anhela alcanzar una calidad de vida óptima, considerando, sobre todo, a su hija de 11 años, que es muy aplicada en el colegio. La sueña siendo la mejor profesional y, a la vez, poder tener una adultez-vejez en paz.

Para empezar a acariciar tal realidad, la señora Pilar solicita encarecidamente un préstamo de 800 soles.
texts.en:
At the age of 30, Mrs. Pilar has more than ten years in the business of heavy transport. In a room in her home she has put a small convenience store/bookstore and in the afternoons she practices her profession: she is a primary school teacher (even though, in a particular way, she does it in her own house). Pilar does not stop dreaming bigger each time, because of which she will realize an optimal quality of life, considering, above all, her 11 year old daughter, who is very applied in school. The dream of being the best professional, and, at the same time, to be able to have and adulthood in piece. To begin to create this reality, Pilar is asking for a loan of 800 soles.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying materials for her store and for her transport business

loans.name: Mrs. Sieng Sok Hai Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Seing S. H. is the leader of a village loan group consisting of four people who live in Rumchek Village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. 

Mrs. Seing S. H. is a silk weaver. She now has a lot of customers who are waiting to buy her products, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more silk to weave in order to meet her customers’ demand. 

Her husband, Mr. Pov Noeurn, is a traditional musician who has been hired to play music at wedding ceremonies. Mrs. Seing S. H. is 26 years old and the mother of a 5-year-old child.

One of the members in this group has an end-of-term (EoT) loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. The member with the EoT loan is not required to pay aN. principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments maN. months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy silk to weave

loans.name: Hina's Group

texts.en:
Hina baji is the wife of M. A. and lives in a historical place named Yadgar of the city Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house and has been living in it for the last five years. She has no children. Hina baji’s husband is involved in a CD and video cassette business. He has been in this business for the past six years. Hina baji herself is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy more CDs and video cassettes for her husband’s CD shop.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics for her parlor. Abida baji wants a loan to buy thread for her embroidery business. Hamida baji wants a loan to buy plastic beads to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy CDs and video cassettes

loans.name: Kaniz's Group

texts.en:
Kaniz Baji is the wife of N. A. and lives in an historical place named Yadgar in Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this place for the last 15 years. She completed her education to the 8th standard. She is the mother of four sons. Her first two sons make paint brushes and sell them in the paint shops. The next works in a factory. Her younger son is in 4th standard. Kaniz Baji’s husband has a livestock business. He buys buffalos and sells them to the market and earns a profit. He has been in this business for the past 15 years. Kaniz Baji herself is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to resell.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Parveen Baji wants a loan to buy candies at wholesale and sell in different shops. Iram Baji wants a loan to buy paint brushes to resell. Naseem Baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo to resell

loans.name: Mrs. Yoem Saroeurn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoem S. is the group leader of five people who all live in Pon Ley Village in Takeo Province. Mrs. Yoem S. owns a hectar to cultivate rice on. In her plantation, she now faces a problem because her field is infertile which it has a bad effect on her crop.

In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Yoem S. has decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to improve her crop. Her husband, Mr. Suk Sorn, helps her on the plantation. Mrs. Yoem S. is 40 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school.

Mrs. Uy S. was not present at the group meeting, but her husband was, so he is in the picture.

One of the members in this group has end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. This member is not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers to improve her crop

loans.name: Carmen Irene

texts.es:
With only ten months of experience in the curtain traD., Carmen, 54, demonstrates great ability for her work. With her children already grown and independent, her concern still centers around them, but also, more and more, in the years that life holds in store for her and her husband who now live alone and, happily, in perfect harmony. Carmen yearns to achieve security concerning her income so that she can live untroubled, something that she and her husband well deserve after so many years. For this, Carmen needs a loan of $200 since, with more capital to invest, she will gain more profit.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Con tan sólo 10 meses D. experiencia en el rubro D. cortinas, la señora Carmen, D. 54 años muestra una gran disponibilidad para con su trabajo, con sus hijos ya grandes y bien formados, su preocupación aún radica en ellos pero también, cada vez más, en los años que le depara la vida a ella y a su esposo, que viven ya solos y, afortunadamente, en total armonía. Añora alcanzar una seguridad en cuanto a sus ingresos para poder vivir más tranquila, algo que tras tantos años se merece enormemente. Para ello, requiere D. un préstamo D. 600 soles, puesto que mientras más capital pueda invertir, más ganancia sacará la señora Pilar.

loans.use: Buy material to make curtains for drapery business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Kosar Baji is a wife of S. A. and lives in a historical place named Yadgar of city Lahore, Pakistan. She owes a room and has been living in it for the last 24 years. She is the mother of four children: one son and three daughters. Her elder daughter is married. The next to her is in 9th standard. Her younger daughter is in 5th standard. Her son is in 4th standard. Kosar Baji’s husband has a shoe-making business. He has been in this business for the past 10 years. Kosar Baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy material (leather, nails and thread) to make more shoes to sell and earn a good profit.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Shamim Baji wants a loan to buy material (colored thread, sketches and beads) for her decorative embroidery business. Nargis Baji and Ishrat Baji each want a loan to buy leather to make shoes to sell in the market.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material to make shoes

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is the wife of A. J. and lives in a historical place named Yadgar of the city Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this place for the last 20 years. She is the mother of six children: four sons and two daughters. Her first two sons are involved in furniture polishing work. The other two are free and don’t do anything. Her daughters stay at home and help her in her household work. Nasreen baji’s husband is a fruit seller, having experience in this for the past 15 years. Nasreen baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now, she is applying for a loan to buy more seasonal fruits for her husband’s business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Bilquis baji wants a loan to buy fresh flowers for her flower selling business. Nagina baji wants a loan to buy spare vehicle parts for her spare parts shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to resell

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen baji is the wife of M. A. and lives in a historic place named Yadgar, in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house, where she has been living for 16 years. She is the mother of five children: four daughters and one son. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. For 10 years, Yasmeen baji’s husband has had a business selling vegetables. Yasmeen baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family.

Yasmeen baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah. She requests a loan to buy more vegetables to resell. Her loan group includes two other members. Rubina baji requests a loan to pay installments of her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Shahnaz baji requests a loan to purchase leather for her shoe-making business.

loans.use: Buy more vegetables to resell

loans.name: Nabeela's Group

texts.en:
Nabeela baji is the wife of N. I. and lives in a historical place named Yadgar of the city Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this place for the last 2 years. She is the mother of four children: three daughters and one son. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Nabeela baji’s husband is a driver and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Nabeela baji herself is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to repair her husband’s auto-rickshaw.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy an instrument for her musical group. Rukhsana baji wants a loan to buy a grinding machine to grind wheat. Shabana baji wants a loan to buy leather for her leather jacket making business. Majeedan baji wants a loan to buy leather for her leather shoe making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Tahira's Group

texts.en:
Tahira baji is the wife of J. M. and lives in a historic place named Yadgar in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house, where she lived for the last 20 years. She is the mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. Her elder son sells books. The other two read in the fourth standard. Her daughters make artificial jewelry and sell it in the community. Tahira baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family.

For the last 6 years, Tahira baji’s husband has had a book shop in a famous book market named Urdu Bazaar. He sells textbooks, Islamic books, and also story books. Tahira baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah. She requests a loan to buy more books for her husband’s book shop.

Tahira baji's loan group includes a few more members. Rehana baji and Razia baji and Zareena baji each request a loan to buy spare parts for their workshop. Sugran baji requests a loan to buy cooking oil, lentils, and spices for her food business.

loans.use: Buy books for bookshop

loans.name: Rorn

texts.en: Mrs. Rorn U.  is 47 years old and raises ducks for eggs in Phteah Rung Commune, Pursat Province. She can earn around $2 per day. Normally, Rorn buys baby ducks from other breeders to fatten for three or four months. She married to Mr. Top Nit, 35, a rice farmer. She has three children, two of whom help farming while the other three are in school. For another source income, Rorn requests a loan of $500 to purchase a dynamo machine to run a rechargeable battery service and to buy more baby ducks to fatten for making eggs.

loans.use: To purchase a dynamo machine to run a rechargeable battery service and to buy more baby ducks to fatten for making eggs

loans.name: Kunthea

texts.en: Mrs. Kunthea T., 38, is rice farmer, and her husband, Mr. Nol Ty, 44, is a farmer. Kunthea has six children, all of whom are single. One daughter is employed as garment worker in Phnom Penh, earning $120 per month; one makes fried cake to sell and earns around $50 per month; others are small and in school. For another source of income, Kunthea needs a loan of $1200 to purchase a planing machine to use for a carpentry business.

loans.use: To purchase a planing machine to use for carpentry business

loans.name: Lorm

texts.en: Lorm S. is 39 years old and sells vegetables and porridge in her area. She can earn around $1.4 per day. She is married to Mr. Chab Heng, 29, who sells wood carvings. They have four children, all of whom are young. To increase their income, she needs a loan of $250 to purchase grocery inventory to sell. The family lives in Kroyea Commune, Kampong Thom Province.

loans.use: To purchase grocery inventory to sell

loans.name: Lort

texts.en: Mrs. Lort B. works raising pig. She has been raising them since 2000 and can earn $2.4 per day. She is married to Mr. Sory Som, 31, who has a rice mill for grinding rice as well as selling wood carvings, earning around $4 per day. Lort has two children and lives in Kroyea Commune, Kampong Thom Province. Lort needs a loan of $300 to purchase more piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to raise

loans.name: Kin

texts.en: Mrs. Kin K., 26, buys rice and sells it for profit, earning around $5 per day. She is married to Mr. Kol Kung, 33, who has business of providing rechargeable battery services, earning around $3 per day. She has three children, all of whom are small. The family lives in Kroyea Commune, Kampong Thom Province. To expand their business for another source income, Kin needs a loan of 3000000 Riel to purchase a motorcycle washing machine to use for business.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle washing machine to use for business

loans.name: Hoeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Hoeurn S., 28, raises pigs. She can earn around $2 per day. Her husband, Mr. Phal Khut, 27,  drives a tuk-tuk taxi (a motorcycle with a small trailer) in Kampong Thom town, and earns around $6.66 per day. They have two small children. To improve her husband's income, Hoeurn needs a loan of $1200 to buy a new tuk-tuk motor so her husband can attract more customers. The family lives in Chroab Commune, Kampong Thom Province. Hoeurn’s husband is pictured because she was not available.

loans.use: To buy a new tuk-tuk motor

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
A married mother of one daughter, Angela Irina works in one of the local marketplaces in Zaporozhye called “Yubileinyi.” She sells men’s shirts and ties. Irina has been in this trade for 10 years. She has gained rich experience dealing with customers, suppliers, and competitors. Presently, Irina has about 8000 Grivnas in merchandise. Her gross income is about 6000 Grivnas. 

Irina is requesting this loan of 6000 Grivnas to increase her inventory, boost her sales, and generate additional income. Irina is hoping to use a portion of profit she receives from increased sales for personal purposes and invest the rest in further development of her business.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Sergei

texts.en:
Sergei is an entrepreneur from Mukachevo. He is married, with two children. Sergei owns a business selling leather goods in a kiosk located in one of the city's movie theaters. Sergei is an optimist. His cheerful personality and unique ability to guess customer preferences make loyal clients come back to him again and again. Sergei has been a “Nadiya Ukraine” client for about a year. He has been very prompt with loan repayment and has not had a single late payment. 

Sergei has about $10,000 in inventory. However he would like to get a new loan to expand the assortment of goods for the fall/winter season. He wants to purchase additional inventory to meet his customers' demands. His rich experience in retail, the good location of his business, and a variety of inventory will guarantee stable income for Sergei. The loan will not only help Sergei make a good profit and promote the growth of his business, but also give him an opportunity to save some money for personal purposes.

loans.use: To increase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is married and has two children. Her family of four lives in Khoost, Western Ukraine. Olena has a small business selling household items. She’s been running this enterprise for 10 years. Olena has gained much experience working in this sphere of trade and has been able to increase her income up to $1,000. 

Olena is a typical entrepreneur who is passionate about her venture and communicates that excitement to potential customers. She is seeking a 6000 Grivna loan to increase her stock. We are confident that the modesty, diligence, and responsibility that have helped Olena develop her venture and gain a good reputation among other vendors will help her promptly repay this loan and allow her to succeed in her business endeavors.

Note: The photo shows Olena with one of her daughters.

loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: Mariya

texts.en:
Mariya is married. She is a small retail store owner who lives and works in her home town of Khoost. Mariya’s business is the only venture offering such a selection of goods for sale in that neighborhood. Mariya’s store has been in business for 6 years. Her net profit is about 5000 Grivnas now.

Mariya can be characterized as a reliable client with a stable business. She is very responsible and serious. One of her long-term plans is to purchase a new vehicle to facilitate business operations and help her be more mobile. Mariya is seeking a loan of 5000 Grivnas to increase her inventory. She is hoping to repay the current loan in 6 months.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Siddiqan M.salamat Group

texts.en:
Siddiqan baji is the wife of M.S. and lives in an area named Walton in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living there for 25 years. She is the mother of seven children: four sons and three daughters. Her eldest son has a furniture polish business. Another son makes shoes. The others are unemployed. Her daughters stay at home and do household work. Siddiqan baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family.

Siddiqan baji’s husband is a carpenter with 25 years' experience. He makes furniture and sells it to the furniture shops. Siddiqan baji requests a loan to buy wood for her husband so that he can make more furniture and earn more income.

Siddiqan baji has several other members in her loan group. Nusrat baji requests a loan to buy supplies such as wires, switch boards, and tube lights for her electric shop. Sakina baji requests a loan to buy vegetables to resell. Nasreen baji requests a loan to buy tools to repair her kitchen stove (cooking range).

loans.use: Buy wood to make furniture to sell

loans.name: Nadezhda

texts.en:
Nadezhda sells retail items (outer clothing, household items, etc.) in one of the local markets of Berdyansk, where she is originally from. Nadezhda is divorced and both of her kids are grown. She is well known in the marketplace where she has been running her business, for her respectful and honest approach to each client and her regular increases in stock. Her business has grown to a level when Nadezhda already has $800 in merchandise. Her income is about $650 a month.

Nadezhda is very accurate in her partnership relations with suppliers. She always weighs all pros and cons and makes all important decisions only after each of them is thought about thoroughly. She is full of enterprising ideas and ready to implement her business expansion plan. One thing she needs to make it happen is additional funding. Nadezhda is requesting a 3000 Grivna loan to increase her turnover capital. She is hoping to repay the current loan in 3 months.

loans.use: To increase turnover

loans.name: Saima's Group

texts.en:
Saima baji is the wife of A. S. and lives in as area named Walton in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the last 4 years. She is the mother of two young sons who aren't old enough to attend school.

Saima baji’s husband has a food business for 10 years. He runs a small hotel in the community and everybody comes to him to buy food. He sells Punjabi foods (Halwa Poudi and Nan Channa). Saima baji is a housewife and helps her husband make food to sell in the shop. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah. Now she is requesting a loan to buy cooking oil, flour, lentils, and spices for her husband’s food business.

Saima baji's loan group includes several other members. Irshad baji requests a loan to buy leather for her shoe-making business. Gulshan baji requests a loan to buy a rubbing machine, which makes floors smooth. Jamila baji requests a loan to buy a welding machine.

loans.use: Buy supplies to make food to sell

loans.name: Alla

texts.en:
Alla is a married mom of two kids. She runs a business selling bags and purses in the local bus station. Alla is very active and energetic. She started this trade four years ago. Currently, she has about $10,000 in inventory. Her gross income is about $3,000. Most of it covers tax withholdings, vending kiosk rent and other government fees.

Alla is seeking development in business. She is hoping to keep gaining stable income from her trade so that she can help her kids get settled in life. One of her other personal goals is to purchase new pieces of furniture for her house. This time, Alla is seeking a loan of 5000 Grivnas to increase her assorted merchandise. She is hoping to repay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: To increase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Shahnaz Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz Akhtar baji is the wife of M. R. and lives in an area named Walton in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room house, where she has lived for the last 22 years. She is the mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. Her eldest son has a decorative embroidery business. Her other sons are in kindergarten. Her elder daughter sews clothes for neighbors at home. Her younger daughter is in the fourth standard.

Shahnaz baji’s husband works for the government. Shahnaz baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah. Now she requests a loan to buy colored thread, beads, and sketches of designs for her son’s embroidery business.

Shahnaz baji has several other members in her loan group. Sugran baji requests a loan to buy masonry tools for her husband. Ramzana baji and Ruqaiya baji each request a loan to buy groceries to sell in their grocery shop. Hidayat baji requests a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell.

loans.use: Buy supplies for embroidery business

loans.name: Rubina's Group

texts.en:
Rubina baji is the wife of I. N. and lives in an area named Walton in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has lived there for the last 18 years. She is the mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. Her daughters are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Her sons too young to attend school.

Rubina baji is a housewife and sews clothes for her neighbors and earns an income. Her husband is a fruit seller with 12 years' experience. Rubina baji requests a loan to buy more seasonal fruits to expand her husband’s business.

Rubina baji's loan group includes several other members. Nasreen baji requests a loan to buy more plants to resell. Haleema baji requests a loan to buy more seasonal fruits to resell.

loans.use: Buy more seasonal fruits to resell

loans.name: Gennadyi

texts.en:
Gennadyi is a businessman who successfully combines running his business and taking care of his family of six. He has four kids: two boys and two girls. Gennadyi is originally from Kherson, a city in the south of Ukraine. He started his business 6 years ago after a desperate period of unemployment when his family didn’t get enough for their most basic needs. Today, he offers English language training and translation services to all willing to master this language or needing the help of an interpreter.

Gennadyi has a perfect credit history. He has already repaid 5 Nadiya Ukraine loans without any delinquencies. This time, he is requesting a loan of 6500 Grivnas to purchase a new computer and hi-tech software which would help him offer better quality language training and more sophisticated training materials for all of his students. All Gennadyi’s students give positive feedback on his services and admit that the knowledge and skills they get at his courses help them in their careers and lives. We believe this loan will also be repaid promptly.

loans.use: To purchase a new computer, software and books

loans.name: Rashida's Group

texts.en:
Rashida baji is a widow who lives in the Walton area of Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the last 16 years. She is the mother of one son whose name is M.Shaffique. Shaffique is a plumber. He has been in this business for the last 10 years. He also owns a shop where he sells sanitary supplies. Rashida baji sews clothes for her neighbors to earn an income. She is applying for a loan to buy sanitary supplies for her son’s shop.

She is joined in her loan group by four other women: Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy electric supplies (wires and switchboards) for her electric shop. Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (flour, cooking oil and spices) to sell Punjabi food (samosas). Rukhsana baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (cooking oil, dry fruits, and sugar) for her sweetmeat business. Sharifan baji wants a loan to buy video games for her video games shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible for the loan.

loans.use: To buy sanitary supplies

loans.name: Roman

texts.en:
Roman Y. is married with two children – Andrei, age 5, and Kristina, age 3 months.  He lives in Kamenka, in central Ukraine.  He has been in business for 7 years, manufacturing and setting up sidewalk tiles.   He has about $6000 invested in materials.  He takes an individual approach to each client, helping with color, shape and tile configuration.  Low competition and good quality of work have given him a net profit of $1000 and much positive feedback from his clients.

Roman is requesting a 3000 Grivna loan ($500 US) for 2 months.  It is a seasonal loan, to buy additional raw materials and parts for the equipment.  The loan will allow him to purchase all necessary materials, provide his customers with trendy and modern products, and increase the assortment of inventory he offers to his clients.  He takes his loan liabilities very seriously.

One of his long-term plans is to launch another startup business to manufacture ornamental fences.  However, three months ago he had his second daughter.  She was diagnosed with brain dropsy (hydrocephalus), and needs to undergo a serious course of treatment.

loans.use: to buy additional raw materials

loans.name: Raheela's Group

texts.en:
Raheela baji is a wife of M.A. and lives in the Walton area of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last three years. She is the mother of four children: one son and three daughters. Her son and her elder daughter are in kindergarten. The others are too young for school. Raheela baji’s husband has a shuttering business. He has been in this business for the last 20 years. Raheela baji herself is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy beams and rope for her husband's shuttering business.

She is joined in her loan group by three other women:. Sabiha baji wants a loan to buy tools to repair mobile phones. Razia baji wants a loan to buy tea and sugar for her tea stall. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy eggs to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy beams and rope for shuttering

loans.name: Viktor

texts.en:
Viktor K. lives in Novomoskovsk, in southeastern Ukraine.  He sells men’s jackets and knitwear in the local market, and has been in business for 9 years.  He is an entrepreneur of integrity and consistency, and is very committed to developing his business in the future.  He currently makes about $1400 in gross income.

Viktor is requesting a 3000 Grivna loan ($500 US) to purchase inventory.  He will repay the loan in 3 months.

loans.use: to purchase inventory

loans.name: Parveen Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Parveen Akhtar is the wife of A. H. and lives in a place named Walton in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this place for the last 30 years. She is the mother of four children: one daughter and three sons. Parveen baji’s husband works in a medicine factory. Parveen baji herself has a clothes-selling business. She buys clothes from famous markets named “Feroz pur Road" and "Azam Market” and sells them in different shops and in her community also. She has been in this business for the last 4 years. She is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to expand her business.

She is joined in her loan group by several more members. Shama baji wants a loan to buy a rubbing machine to use to polish marble floors. Shaheen baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to re-sell. Safia baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to re-sell

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji is the wife of N. M. and lives in a place named Walton in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house, where she has lived for 19 years. She is the mother of four children: one son and three daughters. Her eldest daughter is in the tenth standard. The middle daughter is in the eighth standard. Her youngest daughter is in the fifth standard.

Sakina baji’s husband works abroad. For the last 6 years, Sakina baji has had a business selling clothes. She successfully repaid her previous three loans from Asasah. She requests a loan to buy more clothes to resell.

Sakina baji's loan group includes a few more members. Razia baji requests a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell. Parveen baji requests a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Katherin baji requests a loan to buy a sewing machine to sew clothes.

loans.use: Buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Yuryi

texts.en:
Yuryi P. runs a business offering automobile painting, leveling services, and welding work.  He is divorced and lives in Kamenka, Ukraine.  Previously he had been working at a service station, but he has now been in business for a year and has about $3000 invested in the business.  He is well-known for the nice quality of services he offers.  He has already purchased some new tools like a welder, grinding machines and a paint sprayer.  His business is self-sustainable and has become profitable, with a net profit of about $600.  

Yuri is seeking a 1500 Grivna loan ($250 US).  He would like to use the loan to purchase special lamps for drying paint, which would facilitate the process in winter.   This is an express loan, and would be repaid in a month.  In his 7 previous loans he has never had a delinquency.  Yuryi is very diligent and loves accuracy which only adds to his effective management of his venture.

loans.use: to purchase special lamps for drying paint

loans.name: Ghulam Fatima's Group

texts.en:
G. Fatima baji is a wife of A. S. and lives in the Walton area of Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this place for the last five years. She is the mother of five children: two sons and three daughters. All of her children are enrolled in the local schools. G. Fatima baji’s husband is a tailor. G. Fatima baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy another sewing machine for her husband.

She is joined in her loan group by three other women: Rehana baji and another Rehana baji each want a loan to buy a rubbing machine. (Rubbing machines are used to plain marble floors.) Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy another movie camera for her movie making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible for the repayment.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia baji is the wife of S. M. and lives in a place named Walton in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house, where she has lived for 25 years. She is the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son is a painter. Her younger son works in a garment shop as a salesman. Her daughter is in the fourth standard. Safia baji is a housewife and prefers doing household work and taking care of her family.

Safia baji’s husband has a shutter business. Safia baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah. Now she requests a loan to buy wooden beams for her husband’s shuttering business.

Safia baji's loan group includes some other members. Anwar baji requests a loan to buy electric supplies, such as wires and switchboards, for her electric shop. Naseem baji requests a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Ayesha baji requests a loan to buy clothes to resell. Nisha baji requests a loan to buy another movie camera for her movie-making business.

loans.use: Buy wooden beams for shutter business

loans.name: Anabel

texts.es:
Anabel L. es originaria de Tampico Tamaulipas, y cuenta con 39 años de edad. Ella se considera una persona muy trabajadora, inteligente y emprendedora. <

> Actualmente solicita un préstamo por USD$450 a un plazo de 6 meses, para la compra de ropa usada. Anabel inició en las ventas de ropa usada por necesidad, ya que es madre soltera, tiene 2 hijos, y nunca recibió el apoyo del padre de sus hijos. Anabel tenía la necesidad de obtener un ingreso adicional al de su empleo, ya que ella trabaja en una compañía de telefonía celular, sin embargo, muchas veces no alcanzaba a cubrir todas sus necesidades y las de sus hijos, razón por la cual quería tener mi propio negocio. <

> Anabel comenzo en las ventas hace varios años, vendiendo cosméticos de reconocidas marcas entre sus compañeros de trabajo, pero hace 2 años una amiga la animó para que vendiera ropa usada, sobre todo de niño, ya que se obtenían buenas ganancias y ella la asesoró sobre donde comprar dicha ropa. Fue así que inició su actual negocio, en enero de 2005, primero vendiendo entre sus vecinos y amistades, y hoy en día también los sábados y los domingos en los mercados ambulantes. Actualmente, ella hace sus pedidos de pacas de ropa usada vía internet y las recibe por paquetería, además también ya vende zapatos y bolsas usadas para dar mas variedad a mis clientes <

> ¡Los invito a que apoyen a Anabel para seguir haciendo crecer su negocio! <

>
texts.en:
Anabel L. is originally from Tampico Tamaulipas and is 39 years old. She considers herself a hardworking, intelligent and entrepreneurial person. Today she is asking for a loan for USD $450, which will be repaid in 6 months, to buy used clothing. Anabel began selling used clothing out of necessity. As a single mother, she has two children, and never received support from the father of her children. Anabel had to get additional income to her regular job, as she works for a cell phone company, however many times that income alone doesn’t cover all her and her children’s necessities, so she wanted to have her own business. Anabel began selling a few years ago, beginning with selling well-known brands of cosmetics to her coworkers. But two years ago a friend encouraged her to sell used clothing, above all children’s clothing, as they could make good earnings and her friend helped her acquire used clothing to sell. This is how in January of 2005 she started the business she has today, first selling to neighbors and friends, and today she also sells on Saturdays and Sundays in the street markets. Today she orders her bundles of used clothing over the internet and they are shipped to her. In addition she sells used shoes and bags to provide more variety to her customers. I invite you to support Anabel to continue growing her business!

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy used clothing

loans.name: Ana Amelia

texts.es:
Ana inició el negocio para poder ayudar en los gastos familiares, es madre de un niña de 6 años y un niño de 1 año, ya que como su esposo trabaja por su cuenta a veces no le iba bien y batallaban económicamente, además de los imprevistos como cuando se les enfermaba alguno de sus hijos, es por eso que ella decide emprender un actividad por su cuenta para tener un ingreso extra. Comenzó hace 2 años vendiendo bolsas a sus amigas y hoy en día tiene un mayor numero de clientes.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $450 que pagara en 5 meses para comprar mercancía en su negocio con la finalidad de poder abarcar a mas clientes.
texts.en:
Ana started the business in order to be able to help with the family expenses. She has a 6-year-old daughter and a 1-year-old son. Her husband is self-employed and sometimes things would be rough and they would be struggling financially. Also because of unforeseen events, such as one of their children getting sick, she decided to start a business on her own in order to earn extra income. She started selling handbags to her friends 2 years ago, and she now has a greater number of customers.

She needs a loan of $450.00 USD, which will be repaid in 5 months, in order to purchase merchandise for her business with the aim of attracting more customers.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Erika Mayela

texts.es:
Erika inició el negocio porque su esposo al trabajar como obrero no ganaba mucho y al presentarse la oportunidad de seguir con el negocio que tenía su suegro, se animo sobre todo porque podía estar en su casa y sin descuidar a su hija. Comenzó hace más de 3 años al enfermar su suegro y quedarse ella con el negocio, una tienda de abarrotes poco a poco fue surtiendo más el negocio y lo ha hecho crecer.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $450 que pagara en 6 meses para surtir abarrotes y tener todo lo que sus clientes le piden.
texts.en:
Erika started her business because her husband's day-laborer work was not bringing in very much and she was presented with the opportunity to continue her mother-in-law's business. She was encouraged, above all, because she was able to stay in her home without having to leave her daughter. She started more than three years ago when her mother-in-law became sick and left her with the business, a grocery store. Little by little, she has been supplying the business more and this has made it grow.

She needs a loan of $450 that she will repay in 6 months to supply groceries and to have all that her customers ask for.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: María Eneida

texts.es:
María Eneida es originaria de Tampico Tamualipas, tiene tres hijos y es viuda. <

> Actualmente, María Eneida solicita un crédito por USD$450 a un plazo de 6 meses, con la finalidad de comprar productos naturistas que ayuden a la quema de grasas. <

> María Eneida se inició en las ventas por la necesidad de tener un ingreso extra para subsistir ya que su esposo falleció hace 3 años y la pensión que le dejó no le alcanzaba para sus necesidades. <

> La falta de un apoyo económico, ya que al fallecer su esposo la pensión que le dieron fue menor a lo que él ganaba y aunque ella trabaja como instructora física en el Seguro Social, su suledo es muy bajo. <

> En Julio de 2005, una sobrina, que es promotora de los productos, que yo María Eneidea vende la convenció a que iniciara también su propio negocio con la venta de dichos productos, le gustó la idea y empezó a venderlos entre sus vecinos y después a sus compañeros de trabajo y amistades. Realmente le ha ido muy bien, pues actualmente María Eneida ocupa el 2o. nivel de ventas y planea alcnzar el 3er. Nivel para poderse ganar un viaje por altas ventas. Aparte de los productos que ella vende, también es monitora de actividad física en el IMSS en donde imparte cursos a personas de la tercera edad. <

> ¡Los invito a que apoyemos a María Eneida quien ha demostrado muchas ganas por salir adelante! <

>
texts.en:
María Eneida is originally from Tampico Tamualipas, has three sons and is a widow.

Currently, María Eneida is asking for a loan of $450 to be repaid in 6 months, with the goal of buying natural products that help in the burning of fat.

María Eneida started in sales out of a need to have extra income to survive after her husband passed away three years ago and his pension left her without being able to cover her needs.

She lacked financial support once her husband passed away as the pension that they gave her was less than what he had earned and, even though she worked as a physical fitness instructor in social security, her salary is very low.

In July of 2005, her niece, who is a promoter of the products that María Eneida sells, convinced her to start her own business too in the sale of these products. She liked the idea and started selling them to her neighbors and, later, to her co-workers and friends. Truly, it has gone very well for her. She is currently in the second level of sales and she plans on reaching the third level so that she can win a trip for highest sales. Apart from the products that she sells, she is a instructor in physical fitness in the IMSS (Mexican Institute of Social Security) where she gives classes to seniors.

I ask you to support María Eneida who has shown a great desire to get ahead!

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of natural products to burn fat.

loans.name: Maria Concepcion

texts.es:
Concepción inició el negocio porque ya no alcanzaba con los ingresos de su esposo para los gastos de la casa, ya que al ir creciendo los hijos los costos para que pudieran estudiar cada vez eran mayores y su esposo solo, no podía solventarlos. Comenzó hace más de un año dedicándose a la venta de productos de limpieza y empezó invirtiendo $300 y poco a poco ha hecho crecer su negocio.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $450 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancía y así poder incrementar sus ventas
texts.en:
Concepción started her business because her husband's income no longer covered the household expenses. As their children are growing, the costs to allow them to study kept increasing and her husband alone could not afford them. She started more than a year ago selling cleaning products. She started by investing $300 and little by little she grew her business.

She needs a loan of $450 that she will repay in 6 months to buy merchandise and, that way, be able to increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Esthela

texts.es:
Esthela inició el negocio porque la liquidaron de la empresa donde trabajaba, para invertir el dinero ella decidió iniciar un negocio, aunado a una enfermedad que sufrió su esposo y que no le permita trabajar mucho tiempo fuera de casa, porque necesitaba atenderlo, además de sacara adelante a su 3 hijos que en ese entonces tenían: 17, 15, 8 años, posteriormente nació otro que ahora tiene 7 años. Ella estableció una ´pequeña tienda de abarrotes hace 14 años, que poco a poco ha hecho crecer en base a su esfuerzo y dedicación.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $600 que pagara en 5 meses para comprar mercancía y tener mas surtida la tienda de abarrotes.
texts.en:
Esthela started her business because the company she worked for dissolved. To invest her money, she decided to start a business. She decided to do this also because of an illness that her husband suffered from that did not allow her to work away from the home much because she needed to take care of him and to get her three children ahead who at that time were 17, 15, and 8 years old. Later she had another child who is now 7 years old. She started a little grocery shop 14 years ago that, little by little, has grown because of her efforts and dedication.

She needs a loan of $600 which she will repay in 5 months to buy merchandise and to have a greater selection in her grocery shop.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Elvia Lizeth

texts.es:
Elva Lizeth R. R. es orginaria de Linares Nuevo León, y cuenta con 19 años de edad. <

> Actualmente, Elvia solicita un crédito por USD$225 a un plazo de 3 meses, con la finalidad de comprar calzado para su venta. <

> Elva inició hace aproximadamente 3 años, cuando ella veía que otras personas ponían sus puestos cerca de su casa y tenían clientela, es por ello que se decidió cuando una amiga le prestó un catalogo para que ofreciera calzado y de está manera comenzó ofreciendo productos a sus familiares, amigos y vecinos. <

> Aunado a lo anterior, Elva tenía deseos de ayudar a sus padres con los gastos ya que enfrentaban una díficil situación económica. <

> ¡Los invito a que apoyemos a Elva en su negocio de ventas por catálogo! <

>
texts.en:
Elvia Lizeth R. Rodriguez is originally from Linares Nuevo Leon and she is 19 years old.,/p>

Elvia is requesting a loan amounting to $225 US for a term of 3 months, and she will purchase shoes for sale.

Elvia started out approximately 3 years ago after she saw others setting up their booths near her home and she saw they had clientele. She made her deciion after a friend loaned her a catalogue from which to order shoes and that's how she started offering the products to her family, friends and neighbours.

In addition to this, Elvia also wanted to help out her parents with their expenses because they found themselves in a difficult financial situation.

I invite you to support Elvia on her catalogue business!


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Shoe sales.

loans.name: Elva

texts.es:
Elva R. es orginara de Tampico Tamaulipas, ella cuenta con 44 años de edad, es casada y tiene dos hijos. <

> Actualmente, Elva solicita un préstamo por USD$225 a un plazo de 3 meses, los cuales desea emplear en la compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de tacos y hamburguesas. <

> Elva Inició hace aproximadamente 7 años, primero ofreciendo hamburguesas sobre pedido, mismas que elaboraba en su casa. Posteriormente, compró un carrito para la venta de tacos y ahí empezó a darse a conocer de una formá un tanto más formal. <

> El esposo de Elva es comerciante, y fue él quién la animó para que iniciara con la venta de alimentos, así mismo otro de los factor que influyó en la decisión fue la idea de contar con recursos adicionales para poder hacerle frente a las necesidades de sus hijos, sobre todo las referentes a la educación. ¡Los invito a que apoyen a Elva pues ha demostrado ser una persona emprendedora! <

>
texts.en:
Elva Rodriguez is originally from Tampico, Tamaulipas. She is 44 years old and she is married, with two children.

Elva is requesting a loan in the amount of $225 US for a term of 3 months. She will use the funds to purchase more ingredients to make tacos and hamburgers.

She started out approximately 7 years ago taking orders for hamburgers, having made them at home. Later she purchased a cart to sell tacos and that's how she began to get noticed in a more formal way.

Elva's husband is a businessman, and it was he that encouraged her to start selling foods. Another influencing factor on her decision is the idea of having additional income to be able to cover her children's needs, above all, their education.

I invite you to support Elva that has shown herself to be a hard working person!


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to make tacos and hamburgers.

loans.name: Judith Sanjuanita

texts.es:
Judith es originaria de Linares Nuevo León, es soltera y tiene 21 años. <
