Karena sudah mempunyai induk babi  jenis landrace jero Putu Widiantari tinggal mengembangkan usaha beternak babi dengan jalan menambah bibit babi yang nantinya akan dijual setelah dipelihara selama tiga sampai empat bulan dipelihara dan untuk persiapan pemberian pakan untuk ternaknya. 
      
     Pekerjaaan pemeliharaan ternaknya biasanya dilakukan setelah menyelesaikan tugas sebagai ibu rumah tangga yaitu mengurus keluarganya ,memasak untuk keperluan kedua anak-anaknya yang masih kecil.
Setelah selesai mengurus leluarganya barulah mulai mengurus ternak baibinya dengan membersihkan kandang dan memberika pakan babi-babinya.keuntungan bersih dalam kurun waktu empat bulan dapat mencapai Rp.500.000,-.dari hasil inilah Jero putu Widiantari dapat membantu suaminya untuk menambah pendapat suaminya.
texts.en:
Jero Putu Widiantari just had a chance to participate in the Dinari's foundation loan program called tempek I Manistutu. She used the loan fund to buy a piglet which she is raising now. She plans to raise the pig for 3-4 months before selling it to the market.

She is doing this activities on top of her daily house chores. She can earn a net profit of IDR 500 thousand (around USD 55) after 3-4 months. With this money she can help to add the family's income.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy piglet (Membeli anak babi)

loans.name: Ni Komang Dami

texts.id:
Untuk periode ke II Ni Komang Dami mempergunakan dana pinjaman dari Yayasan Dinari untuk menambah modal usaha warungnya.Usaha warungnya menjual bermacam-macam bahan makanan pokok, keperluan alat- alat sekolah  dan alat- alat keperluan rumah tangga. Ni Komang Dami membuka warungnya pada pukul 06.00 pagi dan ditutup pukul 09.00 malam. Selain menunggui warung Ni Komang Dami dapat mengerjakan pekerjaan dirumahnya sebab warung terletak didepan rumahnya.

Untuk melengakapi warungnya, Ni Komang Dami setiap tiga hari berbelanja di dipasar, selain itu juga ada beberapa barang yang selalu diantar oleh rekan kerjanya.  Saat ini komang Ni Komang Dami tinggal bersama suami dan kedua orang anaknya yang sudah bekerja dan sekolah pada tingkat atas. Keuntungan bersih dari usaha warungnya dapat mencapai Rp. 40.000,- s/d Rp.60.000,- per hari. Dengan keuntungan inilah Ni Komang Dami mencukupi keperluan sehari-harinya bersama dengan suaminya dan kedua anaknya.
texts.en:
For this 2nd loan period, Ni Komang Dami used the loan money from Dinari foundation to add working capital to expand her mini mart stall. Her mini mart business sells various goods such as cooking ingredients, rice, snacks, school stationaries, and daily household necessities. She opens her stall from 6 am to 9 pm. On top of that she also does her duty as a housewife by doing daily house chores.

She usually goes to the market once every 3 days to buy stock/ inventories for her stall. Some of the goods are also delivered by the agents. At the moment she lives with her husband and their 2 children. She can earn a net profit of IDR 40 thousand to 60 thousand / day (around USD 5-7/ day). With this she can help to ease the family's economic burdens.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah modal usaha)

loans.name: Anak Agung Sudaryati

texts.id:
Usaha menbuat banten dan perlengkapan untuk bersembahyang  adat Bali sudah lama di tekuni. Pangalaman ini didapat dari orang tuanya yang sudah terbiasa menerima pesanan untuk membuat banten yang dipergunakan untuk persembahyangan. Kebutuhan sarana untuk persembahyangan sangat banyak terutama untuk dalam acara-acara besar keagamaan. Untuk inilah Sudaryati mengambil kesempatan kegiatan itu sebagai sarana untuk dapat memperoleh penghasilan.

Karena keterbatasan modal yang dipunyai, maka Sudaryati mempergunakan dana pinjaman yang didapat melalui yayasan DINARI. Dana ini sangat membantu terutama pada saat menerima pesanan untuk sembahyangan untuk hari raya besar umat Hindu. Untuk pesanan dalam jumlah yang besar, terkadang Sudaryati mengerjakan bersama dengan keluarga besarnya yang ada disekitar rumahnya. Selain melayani pesanan dalam jumlah besar, Sudaryati juga melayani untuk persembahyangan setiap hari. Keuntungan dalam menjalani usaha ini cukup menjanjikan, dalam setiap hari dapat memperoleh keuntungan bersih sekitar Rp. 25.000,- s/d Rp.30.000,- biasanya untuk pesanan persembahyangan besar dapat memperoleh keuntungan  Rp. 500.000,-s/d 1.000.000,-
texts.en:
Anak Agung Sudaryati is a maker of Banten. Banten is a Hindu's religious article which is used during religious ceremonies and festivals.

She only had a limited capital when she started, therefore she took a loan program with Dinari foundation to expand her business. She makes banten together with her family's members. She can earn a net profit of IDR 25 thousand to 30 thousand / day (around USD 3 to 4/ day). She can even earn a profit of IDR 500 thousand to IDR 1 million (around USD 55 to USD 110) if she gets a big order to make Banten in large quantities.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to add working capital (Menambah modal usaha)

loans.name: Shah Gul's Group

texts.en:
Shah Gul baji, the wife of M. A. K., lives in Arifwala, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 20 years. Shah Gul baji completed her education through the 5th standard grade. She is the mother of seven children: two sons and five daughters. None of her children goes to school. Her eldest son is a mechanic who works in a workshop. Shah Gul baji’s husband makes spare parts for vehicles with a lathe. He has been in this business for the past 20 years. Shah Gul baji is a housewife who prefers to do household work and take care of her family. Shah Gul baji successfully repaid two previous loans from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Now she is applying for a loan to buy another lathe to expand her husband’s business. She is joined in her loan group by four more members. Shamim baji and Shabana baji each want a loan to buy tools to repair vehicles for their motor workshop. Zainab baji wants a loan to buy car wheels to resell. Najma baji wants a loan to buy a lathe.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible. Note: Baji, which means 'older sister,' is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy another lathe

loans.name: Farhat's Group

texts.en:
Farhat Baji is the wife of A. H. and lives in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 10 years. She has one son. Her son is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Farhat Baji’s husband sells plastic sheets which are specifically used to cover tables. He has been in this business for the past 20 years. He buys the plastic sheets from different cities (Lahore, Faisal Abad). Farhat Baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more plastic sheets to resell.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Farida Baji wants a loan to buy cigarettes to resell. Naseeem Baji wants a loan to buy wheat to resell. Faizan Baji wants a loan to buy materials (washing powder, bleach) for her laundry business. Nasreen Baji wants a loan to buy candies to sell in shops.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy plastic sheets to resell

loans.name: Khan

texts.en:
Mrs. Khan L. is a villager in Roka Knouch Tboung village in Kampong Cham Province. She is 53 years old and the mother of four children.  One is employed in a garment factory, another is a construction worker, and the other two children are general workers. 

She and her husband, Mr. Shum Horn, are farmers. On their plantation they cannot cultivate rice because they do not have enough money to be productive, even though Mrs. Khan L.’s family members are involved in different businesses. Therefore Mrs. Khan L. decided to ask for a loan in order to get ahead. She would use the money to buy fertilizers and hire laborers to work in their field to make her crop more productive. Her husband is on the right of photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and hire laborers to work in their field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Anwar's Group

texts.en:
Anwar baji is the wife of M. and lives in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 20 years. She is the mother of six children: two sons and four daughters. Her elder son is a painter. Her younger son is in 5th standard. Her eldest daughter is in 10th standard. Her younger daughters are in 7th standard. Anwar baji’s husband has a grocery shop and has been running this shop for the past 4 years. Anwar baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband’s grocery shop.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Sadaf baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine to sew clothes. Latifan baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (potatoes, cooking oil and spices) to make Punjabi items (samosas and pakodas). Rani baji wants a loan to buy plastic sheets for her plastic sheets selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her grocery shop

loans.name: Nhoem

texts.en: Mrs. Nhoem S. was born in 1961 and now lives in Tjea village in Takeo Province. She owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Yem Yoeun, is a construction worker. They cannot earn much money to support their living conditions, even though two of their three children are working in a casino club. The youngest child is too young to work or study. Therefore Mrs. Nhoem S. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike to allow her husband to easily get to work. Her husband is on the right of photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to allow her husband to easily get to work.

loans.name: Naseem Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Naseem Akhtar baji, the wife of A. S., lives in Arifwala, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house where she has lived for the past 20 years. She is the mother of three children: one son and two daughters. Her son has a paint shop where he sells paints. Her eldes daughter is in the 8th standard grade. Her younger daughter is in the 3rd standard grade. 

Naseem baji’s husband is a fruit seller by profession and has been selling fruit for the past 20 years. He buys fruit from fruit markets. Naseem baji is a housewife who prefers to do household work and take care of her family. 

Naseem baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Now she is applying for a loan to buy more seasonal fruits to resell.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy wheat to resell. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy shoes for her shoe-selling business. Sajida baji wants a loan to buy candies to sell in shops. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine to sew clothing.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Baji, which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to resell

loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran baji, the wife of M. W., lives in Arifwala, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 15 years. She is the mother of seven children: four sons and three daughters. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. 

Sugran baji’s husband has a motor workshop. Sugran baji herself is a housewife who prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy tools for her husband’s motor workshop. 

She is joined in her loan group by two other members. Hayat baji wants a loan to buy more groceries for her grocery shop. Shagufta baji wants a loan to buy a molding machine.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Baji, which means 'older sister,' is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy tools to repair vehicles for their motor workshop

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en:
Habiba has been selling vitambua in Zanzibar for five years. Vitambua is a common breakfast or snack food in Tanzania. It is composed of rice flour that is cooked in oil over coals, in a pan that has round, egg-sized indents. Cooking the snack in this pan and turning it frequently as she does, Habiba produces small, round, slightly-browned, starchy snacks. Habiba sells each kitambua (singular of "vitambua") for approximately $0.15.

Habiba works from 8:00am to 10:00pm every day and is able to earn a profit of approximately $250 each month. She hopes to use any additional profits resulting from her first loan to reinvest in her business so that it may continue to grow.

Habiba is 38 years old, married, and has one 20-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for her food production and sales.

loans.name: Chhoem

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhoem D. is a villager in Chan Teab village in Takeo Province. She owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Nak Hout, is a motor vehicle driver. They do not earn enough money to meet their  needs. Therefore Mrs. Chhoem D. has decided to request a loan to buy a cow to raise and thus add to her business income. 

Mrs. Chhoem D. is 47 years old and the mother of three children who are attending the local school. She hopes to increase the family income and improve their living conditions with this loan. Her husband is on the right of photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow to raise and add to her business income.

loans.name: Maryan

texts.en:
Maryan has been selling soap in Zanzibar for six months. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy a large amount of inventory to jumpstart her business to a bigger scale than the current business.

Maryan is 31 years old, married, and has three children. Her first born is 5 years old, her second born is 3 years old, and her youngest is 8 months old.

loans.use: To buy more soap for her business.

loans.name: Sip

texts.en: Mrs. Sip T. was born in 1963 and now she lives in Trapaing Ampil village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Chum Ly, are farmers and she owns a piece of land where she cultivates rice.  They have four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory and other two are attending the local school. The youngest one is too young to work or study. Mrs. Sip T. decided to request for a loan to buy timber to repair her house. Her husband is on the left of photo.

loans.use: To buy timber to repair her house.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Mrs. Bun E. is a villager in Sam Raong village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Choup Soeun, are farmers and they own a small piece of land where they cultivate rice and vegetables. They do not earn enough money for living and they face a problE. with their productivity. Therefore Mrs. Bun E. decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in her fields. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan. She is 55 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other three children are attending the local school. Her husband is on the right of photo.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work in her fields.

loans.name: Gertrude Nakamya’S Group

texts.en:
Gertrude is the leader of a 4-member group. She is a 43-year-old, married woman with 6 children aged between 26 and 7. Four of her children go to school. Gertrude takes care of two additional family members. She resides in and owns a five-roomed house where eight people are living in all. They don’t have electricity and piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

Gertrude resides and works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She sells fish in Nakulabye market and buys the fish from Kimme Island in Lake Victoria. Gertrude uses public transport to and from the island. She sells to all categories of people, mainly wholesale, and works four days a week. Her monthly expenses include school fees, medication, and feeding the family.

Gertrude has been with MCDT for five years and is presently servicing her tenth loan, working all this while with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to increase the inventory of her business.

loans.use: To boost her business

loans.name: Mboja

texts.en:
Mboja sells charcoal in the Jang'ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar. Charcoal is a common household item in Tanzania, as it remains the primary fuel for cooking food. Few families own stoves or ovens. Mboja is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to increase the amount of charcoal she has to sell.

Mjoba is 29 years old, married, and has one two-month-old child.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Neth

texts.en:
Mr. Neth P. was born in 1971 and lives in Angkunh village in Takeo Province. He is a palm juice collector. He also owns a piece of land to cultivate rice where his wife, Mrs. Chea Sarom (on his left in the photo), works as a farmer. They have four children; one is employed in a factory, another is a construction worker, and the last two attend the local school. 


Even though they have several different businesses, his family does not have much money to support their living conditions. Thus, Mr. Neth P. decided to request a loan to buy a motorbike to add taxi services to his list of business ventures. He hopes to increase his income and improve his living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to add taxi services to his list of business ventures.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea S. is a villager in Angkunh village in Takeo Province. She owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice where she and her husband, Mr. Long Neang (pictured on the right in the photo), work as farmers. She is 51-years-old and the mother of six children; five of whom are employed in a garment factory while the sixth works in a casino club.

Even though Mrs. Chea S.’s family members are involved in several different businesses, they still do not earn enough money to support their living conditions. Thus, Mrs. Chea S. has decided to request for a loan to purchase a cow to improve her farming livelihood. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To purchase a cow to improve her farming livelihood.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
MwanaJ. J. has owned a small business in Zanzibar for two years. She has previously taken out one loan from BRAC Tanzania which she repaid successfully and on time. She is now requesting her second loan so she can buy more inventory to increase her sales.

MwanaJ. has five children, ages 9, 14, 16, 17, and 20.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her business.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha has been selling kanga in the Jang'ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar for two years. Kanga is a local fabric common throughout Tanzania, with any of a variety of elaborate patterns and many bright colors. Kanga is used for clothing, curtains, table cloths, baby slings, and many other daily household needs. The fabric Asha is wearing on her head in the photo above is a kanga.

Asha works daily from 8:00am to 5:00pm and is able to earn a profit of approximately $13 each month. She sells each kanga for between $2.50 and $4. She is requesting her first loan so that she can expand her inventory and increase her profit.

Asha is 30 years old, single, and has no chldren.

loans.use: To buy more kanga for her shop.

loans.name: Mol

texts.en:
Mrs. Mol Y. was born in 1961 and now lives in Boeng Tranh village in Takeo Province. She is the mother of five children: one is a construction worker and the other four children are enrolled in school. She is a pig breeder, and her husband, Mr. Noup Roeun (on the right in the photo), runs a transport service for passengers and goods with a motorbike.

Even though they have several different businesses, their family does not have much money to support their living conditions. Thus Mrs. Mol Y. has decided to ask for a loan to buy four piglets and more pig food to improve her breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and improve their living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy four piglets and more pig food to improve her breeding business.

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en:
Ashura H. has owned a small business in the Jang'ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar for two years. She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $40 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she may increase her inventory and grow her business.

Ashura is 43 years old, married, and has an 8-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her business.

loans.name: Ea

texts.en:
Mr. Ea S. is a villager in Boeng Tranh village in Takeo Province. He owns a small piece of land where he cultivates rice. He also breeds pigs. His wife, Mrs. Keav Tetjany (on the left in the photo), is a cake seller. They have four children who are all attending the local school.

Even though they run several different businesses, they do not make enough money to support their living conditions. Thus Mr. Ea S. has decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets to improve his breeding business. He hopes to increase his income and improve their living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy piglets to improve his breeding business.

loans.name: Ngoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngoun S. is a villager in Deum Pour village in Takeo Province. She is a 35-year-old widow and mother. Her child attends the local school. She owns a small piece of land, where she cultivates rice. She faces some difficulty recently, however, because her field is infertile, and she cannot afford enough laborers to help her improve the soil.

Thus Mrs. Ngoun S. decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer and hire laborers to help her improve her field’s productivity. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and hire laborers to help her improve her rice field’s productivity.

loans.name: Thi Quy Nguyen Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Quý, sinh năm 1952 ( Ms 05030019 ), tham gia vay vốn mức: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng bán quà lưu niệm. Cô sống cùng chồng và các con tại Thôn Hội Phụ, Đông Anh, Hà Nội. Hàng ngày chồng và các con cô đi làm có thu nhập giúp gia đình trang trải cuộc sống. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình cô khoảng 4.500.000 vnd / tháng. Bản cô là người chịu khó, ngoài bán hàng , những lúc rảnh rỗi, gia đình chị còn có nghề làm chổi tre để bán. Trong nhóm vay vốn, cô là người lớn tuổi nhất và là nhms trưởng nhóm vay vốn. Trong nhóm cô còn có: 
Nguyễn Thị Nhiên, sinh năm 1963 ( Ms 05030016 ), tham gia vay vốn mức: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư bán hàng.
Phạm Thị Băng, sinh năm 1965 ( Ms 05030014 ), tham gia vay vốn mức: 3.604.000 vnđ để đầu tư mua lá rong về gói bánh trưng để bán. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnd/ tháng.
Phạm Thị Hưng, sinh năm 1968 ( Ms 05030015), tham gia vay vốn mức: 4.028.000 vnđ để đi chợ buôn bán chổi tre. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.000.000 vnđ / tháng.
Lý Thị Mai, sinh năm 1977 ( Ms 05030018 ), tham gia vay vốn mức: 3.604.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ bán chổi tre.
Chử Thị Minh Khánh, sinh năm 1976 ( Ms 05030020 ), tham gia vay vốn mức: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư kinh doanh cửa hàng giải khát. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng: 3.500.000 vnđ/ tháng.

loans.use: buôn bán nhỏ

loans.name: Mrs. Pum Sreymech Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Pum S. is a farmer and the group leader of five women who all live in Tumnob Leu Village in Kampong Cham Province. Mrs. Pum S. is 41 years old, and the mother of three children: one attends the local school while the other two, at two and four years old, are still too young for work or study. Her husband, Mr. Sieng Mab, is a recycling collector who gathers or buys empty bottles, cans, and plastic, and then sells them to the recycling factory for an income. His business is going well, and he wants to expand it, so Mrs. Pum S. decided to ask for a loan to help improve her husband’s business.

All the members in her group loan have end-of-term loans (EoT), which means they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. This type of loan is AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term, and almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy empty bottles, cans, and plastic to resell to a recycling factory.

loans.name: Toem

texts.en:
Mrs. Toem S. was born in 1970 and now lives in Deom Pour village in Takeo Province. She is the mother of four children: three of whom attend the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice. She faces some difficulties recently, however, as her field is infertile, and this is badly affecting her crops.  Her husband, Mr. Ang Nhor (pictured on the right), is a pig breeder. 

Thus Mrs. Toem S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer for her rice field and four piglets to increase her husband’s breeding business. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her rice field and four piglets to increase her husband’s breeding business.

loans.name: Mtumwa

texts.en:
Mtumwa has owned a small business in the Jang'ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar for seven months.  She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $70 each month.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy more inventory and expand her business.  

Mtumwa is 42 years old, married, and has 5 children: ages 12, 13, 17, 18, and 20.

loans.use: To buy more inventory to expand her business.

loans.name: Mrs. Try Im Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan for four people located in Tumnob Leu Village in Kampong Cham Province. Each member plans to use the money for different purposes. Mrs. Try I. is the group leader. She is a rice farmer, and a 56-year-old widow with three children: one of whom works in a garment factory while the other two attend the local school. Although Mrs. Try I.’s family members have several different businesses, they still live in poor conditions. In order improve their living conditions, Mrs. Try I. would like to start a grocery business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her standard of living with this new loan.

All the members in her group loan have end-of-term loans (EoT), which means they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. This type of loan is AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term, and almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To start a grocery business.

loans.name: Phoeng

texts.en:
Mrs. Phoeng S. is a villager in Boeng Tranh village in Takeo Province. She is 44-years-old, and the mother of three children who are attending the local school. She owns a small plot of land where she cultivates rice, and she also breeds pigs. Her husband, Mr. Kov Seng, sells hens and is featured to her right in the photo.

Even though Mrs. Phoeng S. and her husband have multiple businesses, they still do not earn enough money to support their needs. Thus Mrs. Phoeng S. decided to ask for a loan to buy pig food and piglets to grow her breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy pig food and piglets to improve her breeding business.

loans.name: Sarorn

texts.en: Mrs. Sarorn N., 29, earns about $1 per day raising and selling pigs. She is married to Mr. Nhean Sopheap and has two young children who are in school. Her husband is a rice farmer who also sells carving wood. He earns about $7 per day.  Normally, he must pay his neighbors to plow his farmland. Because rice farming is the main source of income for the family, the family wants to have their own buffalos for plowing. Sarorn needs a loan of 1500000 riels ($375) to purchase two buffalos so they can improve their farming business. Sarorn's husband is pictured because she was not available.

loans.use: To purchase two buffalos for their farming business

loans.name: Mrs. Nay Yong Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nay Y. was selected by fellow members to be the group leader of five women in Tumnob Leu Village in Kampong Cham Province who are requesting a group loan. Mrs. Nay Y. is 34 years old, and the mother of two children: one is enrolled at the local school and the other is only three months old. Mrs. Nay Y. is a recycling collector who gathers or buys empty bottles, cans, and plastics and then resells them to a recycling factory. Her business is going well, and she would like to expand it. Her husband, Mr. Khen Khem, is a farmer.

All the members in her group loan have end-of-term loans (EoT), which means they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. This type of loan is AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term, and almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy bottles, cans, and plastics to resell to a recyling factory.

loans.name: Shahida's Group

texts.en:
Shahida baji, the wife of M. S., lives in Arifwala, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house where she has lived for the past 10 years. She is the mother of three sons who are too young to go to school. Shahida baji’s husband has been selling fish for the past 12 years. Shahida baji is a housewife who prefers to do household work and take care of her family. Shahida baji successfully repaid two previous loans from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Now she is applying for a loan to expand her husband’s fish-selling business. She is joined in her loan group by four more members. Raj baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for hauling. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy an embroidery machine to make embroidered clothes. Anaran baji wants a loan to buy vegetables for her vegetable-selling business. Khursheed baji wants a loan to buy wrist watches for her watch-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible. Note: Baji, which means 'older sister,' is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy fish to resell

loans.name: Zawadi Makame Group

texts.en:
Zawadi has owned a small business in the Jang'ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar for one year.  She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $35 each month.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more of the commodities necessary for her business to grow.  

Zawadi is 31 years old, married, and has two children, aged 5 and 10.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her business.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sim N. was born in 1952 and lives in Ang Tan village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Kam Sarom (pictured on the left), are rice farmers on a small piece of land that they own. They have four children; all of whom are employed in a garment factory.

Even though Mrs. Sim N.’s family members all have careers, they still do not earn much money for their living needs. Thus Mrs. Sim N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow. With this purchase, she hopes to increase her income and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Mrs. Yam Soeung Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Yam S. was selected by fellow members to be the group leader of five people requesting a loan in Tumnob Leu Village in Kampong Cham Province. Mrs. Yam S. is 42 years old, and the mother of seven children. Two of her children are employed in a garment factory; another four attend the local school; and her youngest child is too young for work or study. Mrs. Yam S. is a recycling collector who gathers or buys empty bottles, cans, and plastics, and then resells them to a recycling factory. Her business is going well, and she would like to expand it. Her husband, Mr. Eing Chea, owns a small piece of land on which he cultivates rice.

All the members in her group loan have end-of-term loans (EoT), which means they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. This type of loan is AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term, and almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy empty bottles, cans, and plastics to resell to a recycling factory.

loans.name: Kaniz's Group

texts.en:
Kaniz baji, the wife of M. A., lives in Arifwala, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 12 years. She is the mother of five children: two sons and three daughters. Her eldest daughter is in the 5th standard grade. Her eldest son is in the 4th standard grade. The others are too young for school.

Kaniz baji’s husband drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Kaniz baji is a housewife who prefers to do household work and take care of her family. 

Kaniz baji successfully repaid two previous loans from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Now she is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for her husband.

She is joined in her loan group by four more members. Amna baji wants a loan to buy another bike for her motorbike-rental business. Najma baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Rafea baji wants a loan to buy pesticides to resell. Naseem baji wants a loan to buy more clothes for her clothes-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Baji, which means 'older sister,' is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Thi Hoa Hoang Group

texts.vi:
Hoàng Thị Hoa, sinh năm 1963 (Ms 10030019 ), mức vốn vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà, vịt và đi chợ rau. Chồng chị hàng ngày đi làm thuê có thu nhập. Gia đình chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp và chăn nuôi. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ/ tháng. Chị Hoa còn tham gia hoạt động xã hội và người nhiệt tình, sôi nổi nên mọi người yêu mến đồng thơi là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn gồm có:
Tạ Thị Lý, sinh năm 1965 (Ms 10030017 ), mức vốn vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ 
Đỗ Thị Khanh, sinh năm 1973 (Ms 10030021), mức vốn vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn.
Nguyễn Thị Oanh, sinh năm 19 (Ms 10030022), mức vốn vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng cắt tóc.
Hoàng Thị Hải, sinh năm 1969 (Ms 10030025 ), mức vốn vay: 2.204.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ rau và nuôi lợn.
Trần Thị Chín, sinh năm 1976 (Ms 10030018 ), tham gia mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng nước giải khát.
Hoàng Thị Chuyên, sinh năm 1964 (Ms 10030020), tham gia mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đi chợ rau và nuôi lợn.

loans.use: chăn nuôi

loans.name: Ghulam Qubra's Group

texts.en:
Ghulam Qubra baji is the wife of K. H. and lives in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 20 years. She is the mother of six children: two sons and four daughters. All of her children are enrolled in a school in her neighborhood.

Ghulam Qubra baji’s husband has a animal-selling business. He has been selling animals for the past 10 years. He sells livestock (sheep, goats, and buffalos). Ghulam Qubra baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy animals (goats and sheep) to re-sell.

She is joined in her loan group by several more members. Haleema baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats) for her animal-selling business. Gulshan baji wants a loan to buy spare parts for her tractor. Rashida baji wants a loan to buy a grinding machine which is used to plane marble floors. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer to re-sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animals to re-sell

loans.name: Mrs. Ty Song Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ty S. was selected as the group leader of five people requesting a loan in Tumnob Leu Village in Kampong Cham Province. Mrs. Ty S. owns a small field where she cultivates rice. Mrs. Ty S. is a 45-year-old widow whose only child runs a grocery store. As her child’s business is doing well, she would like to help expand it. She will use her loan money to buy more grocery products to increase the store’s inventory of goods. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this new loan.

All the members in her group loan have end-of-term loans (EoT), which means they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. This type of loan is AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term, and almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of her family's grocery store.

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida baji is a wife of M.. She owns a two-room brick house in Arifwala, Pakistan, and has been living in it for the past 15 years. She has one daughter, who is 3 years old. Zubaida baji is a housewife, but she also sews clothes for her neighbors, which provides a good income.

Zubaida baji successfully repaid two previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband’s grocery shop, which he has run for the past 5 years.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

The loan group includes four other members. Naseem baji wants a loan to buy wheat and corn to resell. Najma baji wants a loan to buy plastic utensils to resell. Kosar baji wants a loan to buy candies to sell in shops. Jamila baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her husband's grocery shop

loans.name: Mrs. Mue Kim Sour Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Mue K. S. is a group leader of four people requesting a loan who all live in Tumnob Leu Village in Kampong Cham Province. Mrs. Mue K. S. is a 39-year-old widow with three children: one is a construction worker, a second works as a recycling collector, and her youngest child attends the local school. Mrs. Mue K. S. owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Her second child’s recycling business is going well, and she would like to help expand it. She will use her loan to buy empty bottles, cans, and plastics to resell to the recycling factory. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this new loan.

All the members in this group loan have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy empty bottles, cans, and plastics to resell to a recycling factory.

loans.name: Pouv

texts.en:
Mrs. Pouv N. is a villager in Ampil village in Takeo Province. She is 40-years-old, and the mother of two children: one works as a grocer, while the other takes care of the house and cooking for the family. Mrs. Pouv N. owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Eim Sokoeun (pictured on the left), is a motorbike driver who provides transport services for passengers and goods. Recently her husband has been facing difficulties because his motorbike is not running well, making him unable to work very efficiently.

Thus Mrs. Pouv N. decided to ask for a loan to buy her husband a new motorbike. She hopes this purchase will help increase her family’s income and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy her husband a new motorbike for his transport business.
